channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: French Journalist Is Detained at U.N. War Crimes Tribunal
item.description: Florence Hartmann, a former correspondent for Le Monde, has been locked up at the tribunal prison to serve a pending seven-day sentence for contempt of court.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Florence Hartmann was arrested on Thursday, before the genocide verdict against Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, was given.

item.title: Al Jazeera Announces Layoffs, Mostly in Qatar
item.description: An estimated 500 positions will be cut as part of a reorganization that the global news organization attributed to shifts in the media landscape.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Shaxi Journal: An Ancient Caravan Town in China Is Reborn
item.description: In a project praised by Unesco, a Swiss-led team spent years renovating the square of Sideng Village, with an eye toward historical consistency that is rare in China.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sideng Square in the old town center of Shaxi, Yunnan, China, in January.

item.title: Who Will Become a Terrorist? Research Yields Few Clues
item.description: The question of what turns people toward violence — and whether they can be steered away from it — has bedeviled governments around the world for generations.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: The operations center of the National Counterterrorism Center in Tysons Corner, Va., in 2005. The backgrounds of people arrested in connection with terrorism-related crimes defy a single profile.

item.title: Blast at a Crowded Park in Lahore, Pakistan, Kills Dozens
item.description: The blast, which appeared to be caused by a suicide bomber, occurred at a park popular with families, killing at least 69 people and wounding around 300.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: An injured man was tended to after the blast in Lahore.

item.title: Mediator: Victory Lap and Wink, as Obama and Raúl Castro Meet
item.description: As Mr. Castro stammered over questions from the news media, it was a reminder of the signs of regression concerning President Obama and the press back home.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG
item.media:description: President Obama and Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro, took questions at a news conference in Havana last Monday.

item.title: Bangladesh Editor Faces 79 Court Cases After an Unusual Confession
item.description: After admitting it was wrong to have years ago published allegations against the prime minister, Mahfuz Anam could be sentenced to 175 years in prison.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR
item.media:description: Mahfuz Anam, center, the editor of The Daily Star, Bangladesh’s most popular English-language newspaper, outside a court in Rangpur District this month.

item.title: Syrian Troops Said to Recapture Historic Palmyra From ISIS
item.description: The end of the ancient city’s nearly yearlong occupation brought a rare measure of international praise for President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: In a photo released by the state media, Syrian forces look over the ancient town of Palmyra on Sunday.

item.title: White House Letter: Along With President Obama, the 21st Century Visited Cuba
item.description: In many ways, including a sharp visual contrast with President Raúl Castro, who is 84, Mr. Obama’s stay showed younger Cubans a prospect for an inviting future.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cubans last week at a wireless hotspot set up on the outskirts of Havana. President Obama linked Internet access and hope.

item.title: Tensions Erupt in Brussels, and Police in 4 Countries Make Arrests
item.description: Memorials for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Brussels were interrupted on Sunday by far-right protesters.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sabrina Esmael Fazal, Nursing Student and Brussels Victim
item.description: Ms. Fazal, 24, grew up in Ottignies, Belgium. She was killed in the attack at the Maelbeek train station.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Israeli Court Strikes Down Natural Gas Development Deal
item.description: The Obama administration has hopes that gas export efforts will help build peaceful relations between Israel and its neighbors in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and STANLEY REED
item.media:description: “The High Court of Justice decision severely threatens the development of the gas reserves of the State of Israel,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a statement.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Keep the Militias Out of Mosul
item.description: Iraq’s government successfully retook Ramadi last year with an inclusive, nonsectarian strategy. Let’s repeat that.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SALEEM AL JUBOURI

item.title: American Tech Giants Face Fight in Europe Over Encrypted Data
item.description: As Apple battles the F.B.I. over “unlocking” an iPhone, European governments are pushing for greater access to people’s digital lives.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: A man taking pictures on the Champs-Élysées in Paris. Recent terrorist attacks have pushed many Europeans to favor greater powers for law enforcement over digital privacy.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 52, Mostly Women, Kids in Pakistan Park
item.description: A suicide bomber killed at least 52 people, mostly women and children, at a public park in the Pakistani city of Lahore on Sunday, government officials and police said, striking at the heart of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's political base of Punjab.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: After an Indictment, Turks Give U.S. Prosecutor a Hero’s Welcome Online
item.description: A Twitter post announcing charges against the tycoon Reza Zarrab has made Preet Bharara, U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, a social media sensation.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, in Albany in February. Mr. Bharara has become a social media sensation in Turkey.

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: With Obama Visit to Cuba, Old Battle Lines Fade
item.description: The president’s engagement policy and Raúl Castro’s minor opening to free-market ideas have created a new dynamic for Cuba that reveals what the country could become with more freedom to evolve.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Havana on Thursday, a man on a laptop and others on cellphones took advantage of a Wi-Fi hot spot. Many clamor for more access to the Internet, which remains extremely limited in Cuba.

item.title: Sent Home to Australia, but Still Jailed for Chinese Crimes
item.description: Part of a prisoner exchange, Matthew Ng says he is now incarcerated for crimes he did not commit in a nation that would not consider his actions illegal.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Matthew Ng, center in blue, was escorted by officers outside a court in Guangdong, China, in March 2012. He was sentenced to more than 12 years in prison on charges of bribery and fraud.

item.title: Another First for Cuba: A Concert by the Rolling Stones
item.description: Cuban music fans hoped Mick Jagger would break down the gates to political and social change that Cuban leaders had already cracked open.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cubans and foreign tourists cheered for Mick Jagger on Friday at the Ciudad Deportiva sports facility in Havana.

item.title: North Koreans Rely on Smuggled Cellphones to Connect to the Outside World
item.description: Mobile phones smuggled from China are an increasingly vital way for North Koreans to reach relatives who have defected abroad.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Choi Hyun-joon, a North Korean defector, on the streets of Seoul, the capital of South Korea. Calls made using a Chinese cellphone helped facilitate the defection of his daughter.
